Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Organizational and Uncertainty Impacts of Couplings in a System Design Framework

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this collaborative project is to investigate three hypotheses focusing on the impact of organizational couplings and physics-based couplings on decision-making under uncertainty in the design of large-scale complex engineered systems. Methods to measure loss in value of a system design due to fixed requirements as well as to organizational incentives are to be developed and tested. Three research objectives are pursued as follows: 1) evaluate the impact of incorporating physics-based coupling information in a system value model to better enable trade-offs; 2) incorporate uncertainties associated with physics-based couplings to determine impact on system value; and 3) evaluate the impact of fixed requirements on the system design. The work will provide foundational theoretical and empirical investigations into the theory of large-scale systems design using a value-based approach. The research will identify the value gap due to organizational and technical couplings and the associated impact on the resulting system design, thereby providing a clear basis for changing present practice.

If successful, the results of this research will demonstrate that requirements, organizational structure, and incentive structures can seriously impact the system value and hence, system design. Further, the research will offer alternatives to mitigate this impact, thereby enabling an increase in system value and improved system design. This can have significant impact on industries and federal agencies engaged in the design of complex engineered systems. For these engineered systems, during the detailed design stage, there may be thousands of individuals working in a team environment distributed across multiple organizations, with many of these geographically and temporally distributed, wherein these individuals operate with different preferences, beliefs, organizational structures, and incentive structures. This research can potentially result in improved theory, methods, and processes to continuity across an organization, regardless of structure, to produce the greatest system value. The results will be disseminated through a variety of conference and journal mechanisms, with the most significant outreach effort focused on a website that will also contain a "common language" established to span fields of Multidisciplinary Design Optimization (MDO), Value-Driven Design (VDD), and Decision Analysis (DA). Papers and tools produced will also be on this website. Outreach to students from under-represented groups will be a key effort, using the special emphasis of social sciences challenges being addressed together with technical issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this collaborative project was to investigate three hypotheses focusing on the impact of organizational couplings and physics-based couplings on decision-making under uncertainty in the design of large-scale complex engineered systems. Methods to measure loss in value of a system design due to fixed requirements as well as to organizational incentives were developed and tested. Three research objectives were pursued as follows: 1) evaluate the impact of incorporating physics-based coupling information in a system value model to better enable trade-offs; 2) incorporate uncertainties associated with physics-based couplings to determine impact on system value; and 3) evaluate the impact of fixed requirements on the system design. The results provide foundational theoretical and empirical investigations into the theory of large-scale systems design using a value-based approach. The research identified the value gap due to organizational and technical couplings and the associated impact on the resulting system design, thereby providing a clear basis for changing present practice.

An example of a complex engineered system (CES) was developed as a testbed to explore both physics-based and organizational couplings in a value driven context. The CES example is a satellite system that includes a geostationary communication satellite, ground station and launch vehicle. A value function was created for net present profit, as well as cost and revenue. Significant results have shown that proper representation of couplings is critical in capturing value impacts of attributes. Results have verified the hypothesis that lack of appropriate physics based couplings in an organizational decomposition will lead to a misrepresentation of value impact. This was observed by demonstrating that change in organization structure impacts the value of a system. This value impact may be a loss or gain in value depending on the time and costs associated with the organizational couplings.

The creation of a Value-Based Systems Engineering (VBSE) framework that enables consistent decision making throughout an organization associated with a Large-Scale Complex Engineered System (LSCES) enabled the demonstration that risk bias amongst decision makers in a hierarchical organization results in designs that are inconsistent with stakeholder preferences. The work demonstrated how constraints and requirements can be captured through attributes in a value function by tracking the paths taken by constraints to affect the system value.

Having consistency in the design of engineered systems via decision making will result in the retardation of cost overruns and schedule delays when developing these systems. Commercial industries and government agencies alike stand to benefit from such advances in the design and development of engineered systems, in particular, LSCES that have been plagued by cost overruns and schedule delays. By improving the design process through enabling consistency, government agencies stand to reduce the incurred costs on project development thereby saving tax payers’ dollars. Organizations in the commercial sector on the other hand are, because of improved design techniques, thrust into the possibility of higher profit margins that would be in response to reduced costs and shorter delivery times to target markets.
